greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the least prime such that the multiplicative order of 2 mod a(n) equals n, or a(n)=1 if no such prime exists.
comment: If a(n) differs from 1, then a(n) is the minimal prime divisor of A064078(n);
a(n)=n+1 iff n+1 is prime from A001122; a(n)=2n+1 iff 2n+1 is prime from A115591.
If a(n) > 1 then a(n) is the index where n occurs first in A014664. - _M. F. Hasler_, Feb 21 2016
Bang's theorem (special case of Zsigmondy's theorem, see links): a(n)>1 for all n>6. - _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Aug 31 2020
link: Robert G. Wilson v, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..606 (shortened by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jan 18 2019)
Dario Alejandro Alpern, Factorization using the Elliptic Curve Method
Will Edgington, Factored Mersenne Numbers [from Internet Archive Wayback Machine]
program: (PARI) A112927(n,f=factor(2^n-1)[,1])=!for(i=1,#f,znorder(Mod(2,f[i]))==n&&return(f[i])) \\ Use the optional 2nd arg to give a list of pseudoprimes to try when factoring of 2^n-1 is too slow. You may try factor(2^n-1,0)[,1]. - _M. F. Hasler_, Feb 21 2016
results.author: _Vladimir Shevelev_, Aug 25 2008
